p: Phylodynamic analysis of real time WGS data can shed light on temporal dynamics of disease outbreaks, for example to determine if there is ongoing transmission ( Hatherell et al., 2016). Here, we employ phylodynamic methods to shed further light on two M. tuberculosis outbreaks. The first outbreak was detected around 1991 in the city of Bern, Switzerland, where twenty-two related cases, mainly homeless individuals and substance abusers, were identified initially ( Genewein et al., 1993). Using a novel combination of strain-specific SNP screening assay and targeted WGS, a tuberculosis cluster spanning 21 years and involving 68 patients was identified ( Stucki et al., 2015; Tanaka et al., 2006). The genomic analysis revealed that this outbreak was caused by a Lineage 4 strain (Euro-American) of M. tuberculosis, and all but one showed no evidence of antibiotic resistant conferring mutations. The analysis revealed three sub-clusters within the outbreak, one of them associated to HIV coinfection (13 patients were coinfected with HIV).
